Just as people think that successful business people would know better how to run a successful economy, people also tend to think that the finance of a country is the same as that of an individual. It might perhaps be helpful for the progressives (or advocates Keynesian to talk more about the differences between the two.

The words "debt" and "spending" elicit certain presumed understanding. This understanding is a context, the lens through which we understand the complexity of high finance and national economy. Unless we can transform or change this lens, the average folks will remain easy prey to the manipulations of the plutocrats who advocate austerity for their hidden agenda. Invoking the people presumed understanding and fanning their fear and anxiety born out of their ignorance and self-centeredness (which we all have in all fairness), I can see the Dem losing the Senate in 2014, then the White House in 2016.

There is something very indecent about the GOP presidential contenders fawning over Adelson in Vegas. But it is even more disturbing that this does not offend the Republicans and conservatives in general.

I think President Obama is too smart (in his ability to not just think, but think in nuances and complexity) and our problems are too complex for the conservative part of this country to handle. This inability will be the down fall of this great nation.

The saddest part of the big picture here is the fact that corporate hucksters hawking "reform" have crowded out actual reforms that could really benefit students without undermining the civic, democratic spirit of education.

One example is the Response to Intervention model. A simple concept, it combines frequent diagnostic testing with targeted interventions followed by retesting. It originated in the context of learning disorders, but its basic elements could be applied to any student having trouble, or performing especially well.

Unlike annualized testing, real-time, repeated testing that targets specific student weaknesses can lead to direct benefits to the student. But since it doesn't profit private companies or wreck unions, the "reform" crowd shows no interest.

You can only learn the beginning of welding in 12 weeks.

For most welding jobs you need to be certified. Certification is difficult and generally needs to be renewed every two years.

If a weld fails the consequences can be catastrophic. A botched weld on a pipeline can lead to a major explosion.

Same for load bearing applications. You do not want brittle welds on a bridge.

Certified welders are highly skillful people and hence well paid. That's why they are in short supply.

Now that the Common Core has deeply underscored the fact that children living in poverty are at a significant disadvantage than their peers in wealthier school districts, will these same corporations and government mouth pieces that have shoved this agenda into our lives be on board with the same ferocity to directly help the most vulnerable among us? Of course not!!! This is all about money. John King is wrong, children who are prepped for these tests do better than children who are not. My daughter's NYC public elementary school is obsessed with prepping for these tests and the children there did fairly well on last year's test. Her school can afford this luxury. Children in the most impoverished pockets of this state will be left farther and farther behind. I am sickened, as are most of the parents (even ones whose kids did score well) and teachers that three months are spent learning how to prepare for these tests. Something is terribly amiss, I am so hopeful people are pushing back. Here's a start: make the tests grade level appropriate or even a bit above grade level, but not beyond one grade level at most; do not ask children to choose literal responses to metaphorical passages or poetry; incorporate fiction pieces that focus on urban narratives so that children in Harlem or the South Bronx have a fighting chance to relate to these passages. I voted twice for Obama, but I am disgusted by his sell out on our country's educational system.

"It's a shame that parents from schools in poorer neighborhoods are resisting the test. The test could be viewed as a great equalizer, forcing their schools to improve academic standards."
- And will you be willing to provide the needed materials and test prep along with the various specialists needed to help these schools improve their academic standards?

I successfully made the application for food stamps in New York City about five years ago.

It has saved my life...but I will say I went to hell and back before they "let me through"...until I started fighting back.

I did it without a social worker or any intervening agency.

Despite the "blah blah" about how they want people to sign up (its good for politicians to say that), the local HRA workers in New York ( it was Bloomberg at the time, but isn't any different now with a new so-called liberal mayor) did the following:

1. forced me to come into a center for an intake interview, where I sat for eight hours, despite the fact that the law did not require my physical presence;

2. I was then slated for a follow-up phone interview, at a time they dictated....which they never kept.

3. I was unable to reach anyone, ever, by phone to keep the process going.

4. finally called my local congress person and yelled bloody murder, and the upper management city commissioners;

5. they then tried to get me to be fingerprinted...(only two states were requiring this) I refused...only way "out" a doctor's note (fingerprinting since eliminated in NYC)

I finally won out...but it took a huge, huge effort.

I am told the HRA workers, as of last week in NY, still not "keeping" phone appts and unreachable by phone.
They are still trying to keep numbers down.

Don't give up....SNAP has kept me from starving.

I have thirty credits past my master's degree. I also have three disabling autoimmune diseases. I qualify for SNAP and get the average amount for singles living alone: $119. I'm grateful for it although I cannot eat like my doctor wants me to on that amount. I worked for twenty five years even though I was disabled most of them. I paid taxes,etc.

I find the forms daunting. I can do them but call a social worker at the community hospital near me before I send them in. I cannot imagine a person of any age who doesn't have the skills I do (I had an administrative job that required considerable state and federal paperwork) doing them.

When I was disabled and couldn't work for some years when I was in my thirties I simply didn't know such services existed. Ironically middle class, well educated people often don't. When I did try to apply for assistance then I was told I wasn't eligible because I had too much money in my pension. It wasn't true but I believed it. I'm still angry about that, which is good. I now look for every service possible.

Savta: Seems like your therapy hit the arbitrary dollar limit imposed a decade or so ago by a Congress for outpatient therapy.  The "therapy cap" is something that consumers and therapists alike have been trying to get repealed, because it it based on total dollars spent for a single course of therapy, with no relation to medical need.  Imagine this:  Would you stand for it if your insurance paid for only $2000 a year for all doctor's visits, then made you pay for any overage?  How about nurse's visits?  Why is this OK for occupational, physical, and speech therapy visits? Contact the American Occupational Therapy Association, American Physical Therapy Association, or American Speech and Hearing Association for more information on the effort to repeal the cap.
Nancy, I was one of those people who also worked hard standing on her feet for long hours.  Before and after being on welfare.   There's no excuse for being cruel to others.

I remember that feeling, too. I qualified for food stamps for awhile after my husband died, but I would use them only when I could drive miles away to a supermarket where nobody knew me, and even then I would hold my breath, wondering if anyone I knew saw me.

And to Paula, as to why Social Security and Medicare are nearly universal, while food stamp usage among elders is not, the reasons go well beyond shame. Both programs are paid for through payroll taxes deducted over many working years and are earned benefits for the elders who receive them. And as any elder will tell you, we continue to pay premiums on Medicare to the tune of about $100 per month deducted from our Social Security checks. The difference, as Molly and others have detailed here, is in not having to go "hat in hand" to welfare offices to apply for food stamps, since Social Security and Medicare are, again, EARNED, not handouts. And I'm not even sure we should consider food stamps as handouts, either, since most of us spent lifetimes paying taxes to support food stamps and other welfare programs to benefit others.

Just a small addition to what's been said: sometimes people who are just one half step away from needing some assistance, maybe food stamps, maybe Medicaid, or temporary assistance...., are the most cruel to those who are using them.  It's about fear I think, combined with human envy over the idea that someone is getting something "for nothing," combined with no understanding of how little that something actually is. It's about another unfortunate human tendency to want to find someone worse off than oneself, all to make yourself feel superior.

And I know how they feel. I once collected welfare for around a month and a half during one bad period in my life. But I was too ashamed to spend the food-stamps I had, preferring to go without. It took me months to use them up.

When I stupidly commented to the check-out person at the grocery store, where I finally spent them, these were the last of my food stamps and I was ashamed to use them, she said, "You should be."
